danfulea.phys

Class XRay

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.phys.XRay

  • public class XRay
extends java.lang.Object
    Core class for X-Ray spectrum generator, HVL and filtration calculations!
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 28 MAR. 2007

        public static int ICALC
        Set this to 1 for using SRS78 database. 0 means using old approach. Default is 1.

    • Method Detail

      • computeHVL12Kvp

        public static void computeHVL12Kvp(int ikvp)
        Computes HVL1 and HVL2 for a given voltage. The anode angle and equivalent filtration must be known! As always, the anode material is considered to be aluminum because equivalent filtration is given in terms of mm Al.
        Parameters:
        ikvp - ikvp

      • computeFiltration

        public static double computeFiltration()
        Computes equivalent filtration (to be considered as total tube filtration) as weighted mean from filtrations derived from HVL1 and HVL2. In theory, filtrations computed from HVL1 and HVL2 should match so this is not quite necessary. If they don't match it will raise the question which one is more appropriate to be used as total tube filtration and/or how to establish the weights for a mean value? One empirical way is to consider radiation absorbed in soft tissue and based of tissue thickness make a comparison with HVL (radiation intensity drop at 1/2) and QVL (radiation intensity drop at 1/4). HVL1 is simply HVL and HVL2 is QVL-HVL so they are related. So, if filtrations don't match this routine performs a fine tunning based on assumption the radiation will reach the human body! As stated above, the filtrations should match regardless if they are computed from HVL, QVL or TVL (radiation drop at 1/10) so be sure your experimental setup for HVL and QVL measurements is appropriate, there are no voltage variations etc. If however you still get different results for filtrations, use this method to estimate a total tube filtration for further calculations such as Monte Carlo simulations for dose assessment but be advise, there is something wrong with the tested XRay tube.
        Returns:
        the result

      • computeFiltrationFromHVL2

        public static double computeFiltrationFromHVL2(double hvl1e,
                                               double hvl2e)
        Based on experimental values for HVL1 and HVL2, computes tube filtration based on HVL2.
        Parameters:
        hvl1e - hvl1e
        hvl2e - hvl2e
        Returns:
        the result

      • computeFiltrationFromHVL1

        public static double computeFiltrationFromHVL1(double hvl1e)
        Based on experimental values for HVL1, computes tube filtration based on HVL1.
        Parameters:
        hvl1e - hvl1e
        Returns:
        the result

      • computeHVL2

        public static void computeHVL2(java.lang.String filename,
                               boolean tissB)
        Computes theoretical HVL2. The XRay theory provides data of unattenuated XRay spectrum based on voltage, anode angle, anode material and voltage waveform ripple. The attenuator (absorber) is usually considered to be equivalent aluminum.
        Parameters:
        filename - the filename containing attenuation coefficients of the absorber (usually Al)
        tissB - if this is true than HVL2 in tissue is computed and for consistency the filename must be properly assigned (TISS).

      • computeHVL2_temp

        public static void computeHVL2_temp(java.lang.String filename,
                                    boolean tissB)
        Basically same as above and called by computeFiltrationn(). The reason for this routine is the usage of different global variables.
        Parameters:
        filename - the filename containing attenuation coefficients of the absorber (usually Al)
        tissB - if this is true than HVL2 in tissue is computed and for consistency the filename must be properly assigned (TISS).

      • computeHVL2_kv

        public static void computeHVL2_kv(java.lang.String filename,
                                  boolean tissB)
        Basically same as above and called by computeHVL12Kvp routine. The reason for this routine is the usage of different global variables.
        Parameters:
        filename - the filename containing attenuation coefficients of the absorber (usually Al)
        tissB - if this is true than HVL2 in tissue is computed and for consistency the filename must be properly assigned (TISS).

      • computeHVL1

        public static void computeHVL1(java.lang.String filename,
                               boolean tissB)
        Computes theoretical HVL1. The XRay theory provides data of unattenuated XRay spectrum based on voltage, anode angle, anode material and voltage waveform ripple. The attenuator (absorber) is usually considered to be equivalent aluminum.
        Parameters:
        filename - the filename containing attenuation coefficients of the absorber (usually Al)
        tissB - if this is true than HVL2 in tissue is computed and for consistency the filename must be properly assigned (TISS).

      • computeHVL1_temp

        Basically same as above and called by computeFiltrationn(). The reason for this routine is the usage of different global variables.
        Parameters:

        tissB - if this is true than HVL2 in tissue is computed and for consistency the filename must be properly assigned (TISS).
